utterance.speaker: Inmate
utterance.content: Deep fried shrimp, and lobster. I never had lobster. What, do you boil ‘em or grill ‘em? Which one’s better? Ah, just get ‘em both. And I know I need a strawberry malt, and then there’s those chocolate donuts that come in a box?

utterance.speaker: Lawyer
utterance.content: We’ll do our best to accommodate. Tomorrow you’ll be moved to a holding cell. That’s where you’ll get your last meal. You also have a constitutional right to the spiritual advisor of your choice.

utterance.speaker: Inmate
utterance.content: Naw, I don’t need none of that.

utterance.speaker: Lawyer
utterance.content: One last thing to think about: After I read the execution warrant, you’ll be given an opportunity to make a statement. You might want to take some time and think about what you want to say as your final words.

utterance.speaker: Inmate
utterance.content: Yo, Clarence! You hear that? A spiritual advisor of my choice!

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Don’t matter, you goin’ to hell anyway.

utterance.speaker: Inmate
utterance.content: You think I’ll get another stay?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: You should. Supreme Court said it ain’t right to kill retards.

utterance.speaker: Warden
utterance.content: Cut the chatter! Exercise time. Be back in an hour. Enjoy.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: Why did you hit me so many times, Clarence?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: You know why!

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: You could have stopped.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: You stabbed me in the back, man.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: I never st –

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: You couldn’t fight fair.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Like you did?

utterance.speaker: Guard
utterance.content: I had a wife and three kids.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: You are a sick bastard! Open the door! Open the door!

utterance.speaker: Man 2
utterance.content: Hey! What’d I ever do to you, man?

utterance.speaker: James
utterance.content: You can’t go in there.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who are you, and why are you wearing a tie?

utterance.speaker: James
utterance.content: I’m Dr. Cuddy’s new assistant. Can I tell her what it’s regarding?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. I would like to know why she gets a secretary and I don’t.

utterance.speaker: James
utterance.content: I’m her assistant, not her secretary. I graduated from Rutgers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm. I didn’t know they had a secretarial school. Well, I hope you took some classes in sexual harassment law. Does the word “ka-ching” mean anything to you? I’m going in now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. House, we are in the middle of a meeting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s with hiring a male secretary? JDate not working out?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: He is cute. Be careful.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s not like you. She can’t just walk into a bar and pick up her soul mate in twenty minutes.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I met Mark at a fundraiser that happened to be held at a –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You met me at a strip club.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You were the worst two dollars I ever spent. We’ll catch up later.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Stacy, it’s House. I know you can handle it.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Nothing to handle. He obviously wants to talk to you alone.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If you have a problem working with Stacy you should have said so.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What was I supposed to do? Ask her to leave? That’s just rude. Death row guy. I want the case.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How do you even know about him? You don’t have access to the hospital’s mainframe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, but “partypants” does.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You stole my password?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hardly counts as stealing; it’s a pretty obvious choice.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, I have already assigned Death Row Guy to Dr. Nolo.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nolo? Well, I don’t want to say anything bad about another doctor, but… especially a useless drunk…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You are addicted to pain pills.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But I’m not useless. Tell Nolo I’m talking over.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. Nolo is a board certified cardiologist.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, good. I’m sure he’ll explore all the usual options for why a guy’s heart starts beating so fast it pumps out air instead of blood. Wait a second – there are no usual options!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How badly do you want this?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I will give you two more clinic hours this week.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Don’t bend over for the soap.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just the heart, or the patient have any other complaints?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The patient’s not talking to anybody.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Where are we going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You are going to the clinic for two hours.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Me? Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Talk to Cuddy. She’s got me going to Mercer State Prison, Capital Sentences unit, I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Aren’t there better ways to spend our time?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good question. What makes a person deserving? Is a man who cheats on his wife more deserving than a man who kills his wife?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Uh… yeah. Actually, he is.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What about a child molester? Certainly not a good guy, but he didn’t kill anybody. Maybe he can get antibiotics, but no MRIs. What about you? What medical care should you be denied for being a car thief? Tell you what: the three of you work out a list of what medical treatments a person loses based on the crime they committed. I’ll review it when I get back.

utterance.speaker: Warden
utterance.content: Your patient shanked one inmate his first month here, broke another one’s neck, nearly decapitated one of my guards…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax, I’ve got a great bedside manner.

utterance.speaker: Warden
utterance.content: Too dangerous to house him in the infirmary. You don’t have to worry, we’ve taken every precaution. I’ve had my men clear from the cell all pens, paperclips and staplers. Any supplies that might be used as a weapon. Open her up! For your visit, we’ve got him cuffed and shackled.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And yet, you’re staying out there.

utterance.speaker: Warden
utterance.content: Uhp! You’re going to have to give me that. Wouldn’t want anybody to get hurt.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m Dr. Cameron. How’re you feeling?

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: Eh. Little cough, no big deal.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Okay. What’re you doing here?

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: I just got a job at the university. They need a health clearance. Apparently I’m a little anemic, so they made me get some more tests.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Any family history of anemia?

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: Not that I know of. My mom died of cancer when I was a kid, my dad’s heart gave out a couple of years ago.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Brothers and sisters?

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: I’m afraid it’s a short family history. That’s it. I had a husband once, but… didn’t stick. My tests should be back, probably in that file.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Probably.

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: Is everything okay?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Did you redo the x-ray?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Twice.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, you don’t need a consult. You know the diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: All she has is a cough.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bluish tinge to the fingernails, lips… he’s hypoxic.

utterance.speaker: Warden
utterance.content: What’s that mean?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It means he’s not getting enough oxygen. You know how people say you can’t live without love? Well, oxygen’s even more important. He’s got fluid in his lungs, breathing rate of 50… he needs to be intubated and put on a respirator.

utterance.speaker: Warden
utterance.content: Don’t have a respirator.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Better get one in about an hour, or you’re gonna lose him.

utterance.speaker: Warden
utterance.content: I’ll make out a requisition. The state’s already sentenced this man to die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think the state was a tad more specific about “how”. This is Dr. Gregory House. I need an ambulance to pick-up at Mercer State Prison.

utterance.speaker: Warden
utterance.content: Wasted call, my men will stop them at the gate. No way a Death Row inmate leaves my prison, at least not through the front doors.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You work fast.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: So do you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Was that a shot?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Yeah. It was easy once I convinced the clerk to take it to Judge Markem, she’s a sucker for Eighth Amendment arguments.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stop, I’m getting turned on.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ruh-row!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It was just a consult! You expect us to shut down an entire floor for this guy?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you do something to your hair?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Stacy?!

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You said you cleared with her –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come on. You’ve known me how long and you still don’t know when I’m joshin’ ya?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Take him back to prison. Now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, can’t. See, ironically I’m bound by this court order which your ace attorney got. I have to make him all better before shipping him back for the state to kill him. Is it just me, or is that weird? Anyway, we’re walking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Somebody left this on my chair. It’s clever. Forces me to either deal with the file or never sit down again.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Cindy Kramer. I told her you’d see her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You shouldn’t have told her that. She’s got metastatic squamous cell lung cancer, six months, tops.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Have you even looked at the x-ray?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, just guessing. It’s a new game. If I’m wrong, she gets a stuffed bear.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A spot on a x-ray doesn’t necessarily mean that she’s terminal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I love children. So filled with hope.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It could be pneumonia. It could be sarcodosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could be, if she didn’t already have swollen hilar lymph nodes on the other lung.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Could we at least brainstorm for other ideas? Thank you. I still think it could be pneumonia and sarcodosis, but we should check for tuberculosis and definitely rule out congestive heart failure. The five stages of dying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly. Personally, I think it’s all just new-age crap, but from your tear-filled, puppy-dog eyes I think I’ve made my point. Now go tell Cindy Whatever-her-name-is that she’s dying. Tachycardia, pulmonary edema, likely suspects?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The Death Row guy? That’s who you’re working on instead of Cindy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: God, I’ve got to learn not to beat around the bush. By dying, I meant no matter what we do. Very, very soon she is going to be dead. Is it still to subtle?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I took an oath to do no harm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, well, it’s not like they make you sign it or anything.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We cure your patient, he goes back to Death Row. He goes back to Death Row, they kill him!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He stays here and we don’t treat him, he dies, and I still don’t treat Cindy Lou-Who.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Can we get on with this?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I knew I could count on your help for your homie.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Exactly, I’m black. I sympathize for guys who grew up in the city kept down by the man.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Makes sense to me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s a bunch of crap. You can’t blame society for the fact that you chose to become a killer. The guy’s probably a heroin addict, that explains the tachycardia, which caused the pulmonary edema.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How does an inmate on Death Row get his hands on heroin?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Are you serious?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The man knows prisons. When we’ve got a yachting question, we’ll come to you. Okay, drugs it is. Test his hair, blood, urine, the works.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thanks for getting my back. I thought you seminary boys were against the death penalty.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I left the seminary.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Over their stance on capital punishment?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m against the death penalty in principle. In practice, however, watching a murderer die causes me a lot less grief than annoying my boss.

utterance.speaker: Guard
utterance.content: We gotta check you out before you go in.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Department of Justice statistics show that it’s a racially motivated form of punishment. Black defendants are ten times more likely to get a death sentence than whites.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Doesn’t mean we need to get rid of the death penalty, do we? It just means we need to kill more white people. It’s okay, you’re in a hospital, we’re taking care of you.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Water… water.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s the differential for being thirsty?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He was just a little dehydrated, and out of his mind. We upped his saline drip, he’s fine now.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Blood and urine tests came back clean, no sign of opiates in his system.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t do that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What, you have some House theory explaining heroin use despite a negative test?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. Only I get to write on the board. So it’s not drugs. What else can cause the heart to do wind sprints? You got the blood work back, any – – thing out of the ordinary?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: His bi-carb is low.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, but which column? Could be the result of the tachycardia, could be the cause?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s the cause.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why, because you want it to be? Let’s see how well that works with your other patient.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’re just talking semantics here. We should put him on a bi-carb drip and send him back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, buff his numbers. Don’t bother trying to figure out the underlying cause. I thought you cared about patients.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Our job isn’t to make sure he can bounce his grandkids on his lap, our job is to get him healthy enough to go back to Death Row.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Our job is to diagnose him. What? Mommy and Daddy are having a little fight, it doesn’t mean we stop loving you. Now, go outside and play. Get Daddy some smokes and an arterial blood gas test. Wow. That was impressive. Okay, what number am I thinking of?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Were you trying to get me fired? If you didn’t want me working here, why didn’t you just say so?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I just don’t want you working right here, in my office. But anywhere else in the building is fine. It’s a big hospital.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I’m a lawyer. You’re a jerk. There’s gonna to be some overlap.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: God, I hope that was a euphemism.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Cuddy just reamed me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I hope that one means what I think it means.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: For trusting you! She figured when she hired me she’d at least have someone you couldn’t walk all over.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The number was six, by the way.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I need to know, can I trust you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I hadn’t lied to you about Cuddy’s approval, my patient would be dead.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Great. Now I know. Now we can work together.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m drawing some blood from your femoral artery.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: From my what?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Runs through your groin.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: You think you’re gonna stick me in the jewels with that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s really closer to your thigh. Technically, at this point, it seems like your jewels are more for display purposes, anyway.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Hold up, hold up. Give me some pain killers, or something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tough guy like you don’t need ‘em.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Forget that, numb me up, man. You got some gang ink? Let me see that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s a Native American symbol. It means “the force of life.”

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: That’s what you tell all these white dudes so they let you play doctor?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yep. Got ‘em all fooled.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: For real, how a brother like you go from gang-banger to wearing a white coat?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How’s a brother like you go from loving a woman to punching her skull in?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Bitch stepped out. Argh!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sorry about that. Guess I didn’t use enough lidocaine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Blood gas came back with a pH of 7.28 and decreased HCO3.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means two things. Most importantly, Cameron was wrong about the bi-carb, and less significantly, we have a new symptom. Anion gap acidosis. Who’s chubby? Come on, pretend he loves puppies. Pretend he’s a human being. What’ve you got?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I think we should reconsider drugs.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He already tested negative.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s why I said reconsider. Back in juvie, I cut up oregano and sold it as pot.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Is that how you put yourself through med school?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What if Clarence thought he was taking heroin, but it was something else?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What “something else” could lead to anion gap acidosis?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mudpiles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, you don’t have to ask. Just wash your hands before you come back.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Methanol, uremia, diabetes…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, it’s a mnemonic. That makes sense, too.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Paraldehyde, INH, lactic acid –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Rewind.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: INH?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yahtzee!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Drugs for tuberculosis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Nearly a quarter of the prison population is infected with TB.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Clever entrepreneur like Foreman here, chops up his meds, passes it off as heroin.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: INH poisoning would explain all the symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who wants to head over to the prison and find Clarence’s secret stash?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fine, I’ll do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great, Chase it is.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I assume you have a reason beyond wanting to make me completely miserable?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ve got a prettier mouth. Better chance the inmates will open up to you.

utterance.speaker: Guy with bandages all around his face
utterance.content: Perhaps I’ll come out looking just as monsterous? I mean, isn’t that what I deserve?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The man’s in a coma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He didn’t mind. I asked.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re getting crumbs all over him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why do you think they put TVs in coma patients’ rooms, anyway?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Some people think they can still hear.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So leave them a radio. His eyes are closed; who thinks they can see?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Do you know why people are nice to other people?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, I know this one. Because people are good, decent and caring. Either that, or people are cowards. If I’m mean to you, you’ll be mean to me. Mutually assured destruction.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Exactly. You’re gonna eat these chips?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You gonna get to your point?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You need people to like you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t care if people like me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: …Yes. But you need people to like you because you need people. Unless you think you can get the next court order yourself. If Stacy can’t trust you, you can’t use her. And that’s not even dealing with the greater agenda – of getting her to dump her husband and fall in love with you all over again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look I know you’re friends with her, but there is a code. Bros before hos, man. Crap.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What is it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Death Row guy is dying.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Bradycardia. His heart rate’s dropped to 30, it’s not going to hold that much longer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you just waiting to call time of death, or are you gonna give him atropine?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Temporary fix?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. Don’t know why those diabetics are all hung up on insulin. They’re just gonna have to have to take more.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Atropine’s only gonna buy you a few hours! We don’t even know what’s wrong with him –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just get out of here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This is Chase.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did you beat any confessions out of anybody?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I haven’t spoken to any inmates.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does anybody do their jobs anymore?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ve decided Clarence’s life isn’t worth risking mine for.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I appreciate your candor. Did you even go to the prison or are you just out playing polo?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m searching both Clarence’s cells. I figure, if he’s on something, it’s stashed somewhere.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless he finished it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, that’d be a shame. He could have shoved it anywhere, there’s envelopes stacked to the ceiling, bottles of copier toner, boxes of rubber bands

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Call it off. Come on back.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re dying. A man deserves a last drink.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: You’re okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thanks. That means a lot.

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: All the tests have been inconclusive?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Diagnostics is more of an art than a science.

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: Should I be worried right now?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I work for one of the top diagnosticians in the country. We’re pouring all of our energy into figuring this out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thought you convicts knew how to drink. You’re at least three shots behind. Now you’re four shots behind.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: You better give me the next one or I’m gonna kill you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House – I was just waiting for test results, I was…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Little busy right now. Getting my drink on.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Unbelievable.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Oof. That’s the finest piece I’ve seen in ten years.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I could’ve hit that.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: And you didn’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eh.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Then you’re the one that should be locked up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell me something, I’ve been trying to figure this out. Why does a guy – – who’s on Death Row suddenly try to off himself? I know you drank that copier fluid. It’s not as visually dramatic as slitting your wrists with a homemade shiv, but it’ll do the trick.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: It just hit me all of a sudden. It was like, they tell me when to eat, when to sleep, when to walk, when to talk, everything. I had to take control of something, right? When to die, I figured that was as good as anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And that thought just came to you. Just like that.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Man, I told you. Twenty-three hours a –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mmm. Well, look. Here’s the good news. The copier fluid you drank contains about 90% methanol, which is very poisonous and you took more than enough to kill yourself. The bad news is the alcohol you just drank contains so much ethanol that it’s gonna bind with that nasty formic acid raging through your body, and you’re just gonna pee it out. Harmlessly.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Man, you are drunk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, I am. I also saved your life. At least for now.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Morning! Your head hurt?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you just have a very grating voice.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You always were a light weight.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you talking to me?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Can’t it be enough that I want to cause you pain? The patient’s okay now, you’re going to send him back?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely. Can I trust you?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You used to.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I still think the patient’s sick. I’m keeping him here. Now, either you can do your job and keep the hospital informed, or you can help me make sure the hospital is not informed and buy me some time.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Have you done a CT?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, I have.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: With contrast?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s done everything she needs to do except tell her patient that she’s dying. I told you, only I get to play with the markers. Our prisoner has a new symptom.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not telling Cindy she’s dying until the diagnosis is confirmed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not buying that CLARENCE is trying to take control of his life by suicide. Healthy people don’t kill themselves.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Healthy people don’t kill other people.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guy just filed an appeal in a state that hasn’t actually killed anybody in about 30 years.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What if it wasn’t suicide? What if it was an escape plan? Drink enough methanol to get transferred to a hospital, try to escape from here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Excellent. Explains everything, except the symptom that got him here. His heart went nuts before he got stuck in that storage cell and chugged a toner martini. I think there’s something going on in his head. Check for intracranial lesions, brain infections, autoimmune diseases… do a CT, LP, full workup. State’s paying, so go nuts.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where’d you get these scars?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: I got shived my first month in. After I healed up I got mines. You guys still think I’m sick?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Obviously.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Why you care? Why don’t you just let me die?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, I’m different than you.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Right, you love me like your own mama. That’s why the nurse says you kicked her out when my heart nearly stopped.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Take a deep breath. Any family history of mental illness?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: I always heard my pa was crazy; I never met the man. With my mom, it was the drugs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Any siblings?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Got a brother, pretty much raised him on my own.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Inspirational story. He doin’ time, too?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Hey. He’s a good kid. Don’t go judgin’ what you don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How’s his health?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: I haven’t heard from him since I went inside. Spent 16 years with him, changed his damn diapers. Can you imagine your whole life bein’ about the worst thing you ever did?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You killed four people. Somehow, making mac and cheese just the way he wants kind of loses its significance.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh no. Now you’ve left your entire body in my chair. What does that mean you want?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I need a segmental bronchoalveolar lavage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I take it the CT with contrast came back.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: They’re not definitive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Biopsy would be.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Biopsy would be invasive and unnecessary.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And definitive. But you don’t want definitive, you want to hang on to your delusions as long as you can.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A lavage could prove it’s not cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you need me to approve the procedure. Must be a bitch. The answer is no.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why? Because it’s me? I’m over you. I’ve jumped on the bandwagon. I hate you, okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great. Let’s treat her.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What is it? You won’t help Cindy but you’re obsessed with this piece of dirt! Are you just trying to prove that who someone is doesn’t matter, that all that matters is your stupid puzzle? Fine. Treat them the same. That’s all I’m asking. One test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow, that is remarkable. According to those patchouli-oli selling new-agers, it’s supposed to be the terminal patient, but you’re going through the five stages. You just made a completely seamless transition from anger to bargaining. Cover two more of my clinic hours, and you can have your one procedure.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No lesions, no aneurysms. Ironically, the mind of a killer looks completely normal.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If someone asks you to describe me to them, what’s the first thing you’d tell them?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Insecure. What are you asking?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Like, if you were setting me up on a blind date. Would you describe me to the girl as the black guy, a neurologist, car thief?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This guy’s really getting to you, isn’t he?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s no sign of infection.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re gonna have to do the biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your Death Row guy’s still here!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, sorry. Just gotta get him stabilized. Probably keep him on fluids for a few more hours, then off he goes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh yeah? ‘Cause I’m figuring that you still think he’s sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Figuring requires deductive reasoning. I’m figuring that you did no figuring. Stacy just ratted me out, right? So much for attorney-client privledge.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m the client, you moron. Stacy has a duty to this hospital.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m sending him back to prison.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whoa, can’t. Court order.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Court order says he has to be declared healthy. Doesn’t specify what doctor needs to make that declaration.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What is it, Clarence?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: My gut!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Would you describe it as a shooting pain? A throbbing pain? Or maybe an imaginary pain because you don’t want to go back to prison?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where does it hurt?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: My gut, I feel like I’m getting stabbed!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, he’d know. Let me take a look.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, so everybody lies except a convicted murderer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t think he’s faking this stuff. What do you think, Doctor?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I didn’t have any choice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you had to tell Cuddy. She’s your boss, I get it. Hitler thought he was doing the world a favor, too.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Yeah, pretty much on that same level.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gandhi didn’t march the sea because his buddies asked him too, Pol Pot didn’t wipe out the teachers because he wanted to make friends.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You’re not making friends right now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I trusted you.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wilson’s a fool. I’m an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I had to do what I thought was right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s the only reason anybody does anything.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The surgery went fine. They removed almost a foot of necrotic bowel. They’re shackling him and taking him to recovery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I wonder. I wonder why Clarence killed that second inmate.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fine, I’ll bite. What the hell are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everything we do is dictated by motive. Why did he kill his girlfriend?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Because he’s a maniac!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is that the reason he gave?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She was cheating on him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Jealousy. That gets him sent to prison, where he kills inmate number one. Why?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Guy attacked him first.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Revenge. Who’d he killed after that?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Prison guard.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who had a file full of abusive complaints. Probably been kicking Clarence’s ass for months.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Clarence is just ridding the world of bad seeds.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Call that one “retribution”. Then he kills inmate number two. Anybody know why? Nuh-uh. It’s not in there.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: All of a sudden I got to have a reason?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s an anomaly. Doctors love anomalies. Dark spot on an x-ray, bright spot on an MRI…. Killing that second inmate is the homicidal equivalent of blood in the urine. It doesn’t fit. I’m interested in things that don’t fit. Tell me why you did it. Your other victims you were almost bragging about. What was different about this guy?

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: It happened when I was in gen-pop. I was in the library, just readin’, and I started feelin’ real nervous. This guy was staring at me, I could feel his eyes digging holes in the back of my neck, it made me feel crazy. Sweat was pouring down my face. I could hear my heartbeat racing in my ears. I just raged out on the dude.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what’s the differential for raging out?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Excess testosterone, steroids –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Adrenaline –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Prep Clarence for surgery.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Care to share with the class.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, come on. Do I have to spell it out for you? Pheochromocytoma. Actually, I’m not sure how you spell it. But you said it yourself, adrenaline. Pheochomocytoma sits on top of the adrenal gland, randomly spits out oodles of the stuff. It’s perfect, it explains everything. The tachycardia, pulmonary edema, the vasoconstriction that caused the necrotic bowel –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Even explains how he had the strength to rip the rail off his bed.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But pheo’s extremely rare.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I love rare. Set up an MRI. Where’s Cameron? Like I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Dr. Cameron? Could I borrow you for a consult? Bittersweet thing about being head of the oncology department, I get CCed in all the biopsy results.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, I know. She’s terminal.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. So I take it you were in there informing her?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Well, I… I hadn’t exactly gotten around to that, but I was just –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Doing what? Making friends?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Cindy’s divorced. She doesn’t have any kids, no siblings, both her parents are gone –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s not your job to be her friend. Do you understand? And it’s not worth it. She feels better her few final days, and you’re not the same, maybe for years.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You don’t think it’s worth it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I know it’s not worth it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: My husband w – I met him just after he was diagnosed with terminal brain cancer. If I hadn’t married him, he was alone. When a good person dies, there should be an impact on the world. Somebody should notice. Somebody should be upset.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Pheo what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t even remember. It’s just a fancy way of saying small, adrenaline-secreting tumor. Yeah, that clarified it for you. All you need to know is if I’m right, we can fix it. Just gotta to find it first. We need an MRI. It’s completely painless for most people.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: But not for me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I assume you got those tattoos in prison. Prison tats often contain inks with heavy metals. The MRI’s basically a giant magnet. It’d suck those metallic inks right out of your skin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stop squirming. Don’t make us do this again. Big baby.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Still don’t see anything.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Turn it off!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s Waldo. Found it, Clarence.

utterance.speaker: Clarence
utterance.content: Turn it off! Turn this damn thing off!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Keep him in there until you guys see it too.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Son of a bitch.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Looks like they got the pheo out successfully. So what now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Clarence goes back to Death Row.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just like that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s cured.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That tumor caused random shots of adrenaline, which obviously led to the rage attacks that made him become a murderer in the first place.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My God, you’re right! Let’s call the surgeons, we’ve got to save that tumor. Put it on the witness stand.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We could testify at Clarence’s appeal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You smell that? I think that is the stink of hypocrisy. You wouldn’t even consider the notion that Clarence’s social upbringing was responsible for what he became, but now you’re sprinting to the witness stand to blame everything on a little tumor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A person’s upbringing and their biology are completely different.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. See, you only overcame one of them. Well, let’s just give Clarence a free pass, hmmm? Which, is probably going to piss off all those other pheo sufferers who managed to control their rage attacks and become lawyers, race car doctors, or even doctors. Removing that tumor puts a stop to those random shots adrenaline, it doesn’t absolve him.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You want him to be executed?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not what I’m saying.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Got an opinion?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Everyone’s got an opinion.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I, um, I think I’m gonna testify at Clarence’s appeal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ll do what you think is right. On your own time.

utterance.speaker: Cindy
utterance.content: But it’s just a cough.
